STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 13, 2022
Rick Sanville
Upper Peninsula Family Solutions
369 US 41 East
Negaunee, MI 49866
RE: License #: CB520304693
Upper Peninsula Family Solutions
369 US 41 East
Negaunee, MI 49866
Dear Mr. Sanville:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
3/28-4/1/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a written
evaluation of the convictions that addresses the nature of the
conviction, the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity.
1 of 4 newly hired staff files reviewed did not contain the required chief administrator
write up regarding criminal history.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(g) A written statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
1 of 4 newly hired staff files reviewed did not contain the required or employee write
up regarding criminal history.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
1 of 4 newly hired staff files reviewed contained documentation that the clearance
was received after the employee was hired.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
4

1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained documentation indicating that a
renewal application was not provided to the family within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 5/7/2020, CAP Approved 5/8/2020
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least annually
and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
2 of 6 open foster home files reviewed did not contain an annually signed
agreement.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
3 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained documentation indicating that
recommendation was not made to the department within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 7/14/2021, CAP Approved 7/16/21
Renewal 5/7/2020, CAP Approved 5/8/2020
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as
is indicated, based on the information received, but not later
than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
1 of 4 open foster home files containing special evaluations reviewed contained an
evaluation during which the worker did not complete interviews or obtain
documentation to determine a foster parent's verbal response to the allegation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
5

(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
1 of 4 open foster home files containing special evaluations did not contain
documentation that the foster parent was provided with a copy of the report or
notified of their right to provide a written response.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
1 of 4 open foster home files containing special evaluations did not contain
documentation that the assigned foster care worker was notified of the evaluation
outcome.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
1 of 4 open foster home files containing special evaluations reviewed contained a
corrective action plan that did not adequately address the violation.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a-i)
1 of 7 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain 3307/placement outlines
for placement changes.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
6

2 of 7 total open case files reviewed (6FC, 1IL) contained one late USP each.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 7/14/2021, CAP Approved 7/16/21
Renewal 5/7/2020, CAP Approved 5/8/2020
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient to
meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous
expenses.
1 of 1 file of a youth in an independent living placement did not contain
documentation of the required monthly budget.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
1 of 1 file of a youth in an independent living placement did not contain
documentation of the required contracts.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MSA requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
7

Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
2 of 7 total open case files reviewed (6 FC, 1 IL) did not contain documentation that
all required FTMs were held/all required paperwork was uploaded.
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
8

the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
3 of 7 total open case files reviewed (6 FC, 1 IL) did not contain all required
signatures, obtained as required.
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
2 of 8 (6 open, 2 closed) foster care case files reviewed were missing action
summaries for a placement change and for case closing.
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
9

For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed was missing required medical passport
documentation.
ADM 980 ADOPTION CLOSING SUMMARY (DHS-222)
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14 calendar
days of the adoption finalization date to the foster care worker
and the Department of Health and Services (DHHS) adoption
monitor for purchase of service cases for inclusion in the child’s
permanent record. The DHS-222, Adoption Closing Summary
must be used for this purpose.
2 of 2 closed adoption youth files did not contain the closing summary completed
within the required timeframe.
10

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Foster home evaluations must include the dates Emergency Procedures
practiced as the report format requests.
 When endorsing documents for the purposes of borrowing beds, the endorsing
person’s signature must be dated.
 If paperwork is unable to be signed by FP prior to/at placement, then be sure to
obtain either virtual signatures or document on each form that the documents
were reviewed via phone/email/etc. prior to placement.
 All references for potential employees must document the date the reference was
completed.
 Employee files must contain official transcripts.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Foster home renewal letter did not indicate an application was provided with the
letter. It was recommended this be included in the letter.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
The investigation was reviewed and found to be completed thoroughly and
accurately.
There were 2 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The investigations were reviewed and no concerns were noted other than those for
which violations are established within this report.
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR 2021C0106035 9/30/2021, CAP Approved 10/6/2021 – This CAP addressed the
use of confidential information by including the allegation email form the referral
source in the report. The agency remains in compliance with this CAP as evidenced
by a lack of confidential information in the SERs reviewed during this inspection.
Interim Inspection 7/14/2021, CAP Approved 7/16/2021 – The agency is not
compliance with two of the three areas addressed in that CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator identified areas in need of improvement indicating that a main
barrier to compliance is challenges with the MiSACWIS system not being an effective
11

system. It was discussed with the chief administrator that the responsibility is on the
agency staff to seek additional system training, if needed and to submit helpdesk
tickets when the system is not working as intended.
Staff Interviews
All of the staff interviewed reported that they enjoy working at the agency and feel that
they have a supportive and knowledgeable team.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified 3 safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert: The children’s bedroom did not have flooring. Clutter and a wood stove
in the home presented safety risk for a young, mobile child.
Resolution: The flooring has been installed. The agency staff provided photos of the
installed flooring, which I reviewed. The agency purchased totes for organizing clutter
and a gate for the pellet stove. The agency is working on securing funding for
dressers and toy chests as well as a dumpster to help de-clutter the home. The
agency staff provided photos of the installed gate surrounding the pellet stove, which I
reviewed.
Safety Alert: No smoke alarms between sleeping areas.
Resolution: The agency provided photos of smoke detectors installed between both
sleeping areas of the home as well is in the kitchen.
Safety Alert: No smoke alarms on the second floor of the home.
Resolution: The agency provided photos of smoke detectors installed on the second
level of the home, which I reviewed.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued
a renewal of their regular license.
April 13, 2022
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
12

April 13, 2022

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
